required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Optimizing HPV Vaccine Introduction in Shanghai, China
clinical_study.official_title: Optimizing HPV Vaccine Introduction in Shanghai, China

collaborator.agency: Shanghai Municipal Center for Disease Control and Prevention
National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID)

brief_summary.textblock: Within low, middle, and upper income countries, low vaccine coverage results from both obstacles to vaccine access and low confidence in vaccine programs. Thus, it is critical to determine how best to enhance trust in vaccines as increasing numbers of vaccines are recommended for use. Even though the context accompanying the initial roll-out of a vaccine can have a large impact on people's perceptions of the vaccine and the corresponding disease, it is not clear how to best introduce a vaccine to increase public confidence and enhance uptake. The US roll-out of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine framed HPV as a sexually transmitted infection, which proved to be an impediment to efforts to increase vaccine uptake >10 years after its introduction. This study will use an educational experiment, where parents of children will be exposed to information about the HPV vaccination in different ways. Parents will be introduced to the HPV vaccine through different scenarios with varying emphases (i.e., age at vaccination, types of transmission, type of cancer prevention). The aim will be to determine how the framing of the HPV vaccination across several dimensions affects (A) short-term and (B) sustained willingness to receive it. Parents' willingness to receive the vaccine will be assessed at this time and in the future.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: In this educational intervention, there are three dimensions of variability: cancer messaging, communicability messaging, and age messaging. For cancer messaging there are two possibilities: one message focused more on cervical cancer, one message on cancer in general. For communicability, one message will have information on sexual transmission, a second on infectiousness in general, and a third will have no information about communicability. For age, one will mention that the vaccine is available for 9-45 year olds, the second will mention that and additionally recommend children 11 years old to receive the vaccine, and the third will recommend children 18 years old to receive the vaccine.

primary_outcome.measure: To Determine How the Framing of the HPV Vaccination Across Several Dimensions Affects Short-term Willingness to Receive it
primary_outcome.description: Immediately after the experimental component, parents will respond to the question "If you had a daughter, how willing would you be to give your daughter an HPV vaccine at 12 years of age?" This will be assessed on a 5-point scale from "not at all willing" (1) to "very willing" (5). The proportion of parents who select "somewhat" (4) or "very willing" (5) will be tallied as the primary outcome measure.

secondary_outcome.measure: To Determine How the Framing of the HPV Vaccination Across Several Dimensions Affects Sustained Willingness to Receive it
secondary_outcome.description: Three years after the experimental component, parents will respond to the question "If you had a daughter, how willing would you be to give your daughter an HPV vaccine at 12 years of age?" This will be assessed on a 5-point scale from "not at all willing" (1) to "very willing" (5). The proportion of parents who select "somewhat" (4) or "very willing" (5) will be tallied as the primary outcome measure.

arm_group.description: The Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) causes cervical cancer. HPV is a sexually transmitted disease. Currently, safe and effective HPV vaccines are available for women 9-45 years of age in China.

The Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) causes cervical cancer. HPV is a sexually transmitted disease. Currently, safe and effective HPV vaccines are available for women 9-45 years of age in China. The transition between grade school and middle school is a particularly good time to think about the HPV vaccine.

The Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) causes cervical cancer. HPV is a sexually transmitted disease. Currently, safe and effective HPV vaccines are available for women 9-45 years of age in China. The transition between high school and college or work is a particularly good time to think about the HPV vaccine.

intervention.description: Caregivers receive information that HPV causes more than just cervical cancer.
Caregivers learn that HPV is an STD.
Caregivers learn that HPV is infectious (but information that it is an STD is omitted).
Caregivers are prompted to get their child vaccinated when the child is 12 years old.
Caregivers are prompted to get their child vaccinated when the child is 18 years old.
Caregivers are given information about when the HPV vaccination can be given in China, but no additional recommendations.
Caregivers are told that HPV causes cervical cancer.
Caregivers are not given any information on how HPV is spread.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Parents of children 2-18 years old.
Exclusion Criteria:
- None

patient_data.ipd_description: The dataset will be uploaded to a public repository after each wave of data collection is complete. The data for each participant will at minimum include the experimental condition and the primary and secondary outcomes.
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: Wave 1 (aim 1): data available end of 2019 Wave 2 (aim 2): data available end of 2022
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: The data will be made freely available after any personally identifiable information is removed.

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruitment period: summer 2019 Recruitment locations: immunization clinics and schools in 40 townships in Shanghai, China

group.title: Cervical Cancer - Sexually Transmitted (STD) - Standard
group.description: The Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) causes cervical cancer. HPV is a sexually transmitted disease. Currently, safe and effective HPV vaccines are available for women 9-45 years of age in China. Information about STDs: Caregivers learn that HPV is an STD. Standard age information: Caregivers are given information about when the HPV vaccination can be given in China, but no additional recommendations. Cervical cancer: Caregivers are told that HPV causes cervical cancer.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

measure.title: Race and Ethnicity Not Collected
measure.population: Race and Ethnicity were not collected from any participant.

measure.title: Vaccinated at baseline
measure.description: Response to the question: "Has one of your children already received the HPV vaccine?"

outcome.title: To Determine How the Framing of the HPV Vaccination Across Several Dimensions Affects Short-term Willingness to Receive it
outcome.description: Immediately after the experimental component, parents will respond to the question "If you had a daughter, how willing would you be to give your daughter an HPV vaccine at 12 years of age?" This will be assessed on a 5-point scale from "not at all willing" (1) to "very willing" (5). The proportion of parents who select "somewhat" (4) or "very willing" (5) will be tallied as the primary outcome measure.

group.description: The Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) causes cervical cancer. HPV is a sexually transmitted disease. Currently, safe and effective HPV vaccines are available for women 9-45 years of age in China. The transition between grade school and middle school is a particularly good time to think about the HPV vaccine. Information about STDs: Caregivers learn that HPV is an STD. Recommendation for children 12 years old: Caregivers are prompted to get their child vaccinated when the child is 12 years old. Cervical cancer: Caregivers are told that HPV causes cervical cancer.

measure.title: To Determine How the Framing of the HPV Vaccination Across Several Dimensions Affects Short-term Willingness to Receive it
measure.description: Immediately after the experimental component, parents will respond to the question "If you had a daughter, how willing would you be to give your daughter an HPV vaccine at 12 years of age?" This will be assessed on a 5-point scale from "not at all willing" (1) to "very willing" (5). The proportion of parents who select "somewhat" (4) or "very willing" (5) will be tallied as the primary outcome measure.

outcome.title: To Determine How the Framing of the HPV Vaccination Across Several Dimensions Affects Sustained Willingness to Receive it
outcome.description: Three years after the experimental component, parents will respond to the question "If you had a daughter, how willing would you be to give your daughter an HPV vaccine at 12 years of age?" This will be assessed on a 5-point scale from "not at all willing" (1) to "very willing" (5). The proportion of parents who select "somewhat" (4) or "very willing" (5) will be tallied as the primary outcome measure.

reported_events.desc: This study is an educational/behavioral intervention. Any “physical” adverse event is not expected to occur. This study could change someone’s attitude about the HPV vaccine for the worse - a behavioral/attitudinal adverse event. If acceptability of the vaccine is less than 40% (about 10% to 20% less than acceptability of what was found in previous studies), data collection will be temporarily stopped.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
